thread.title: Asciano backs revised $12bn buyout bid backed by US fund Brookfield Infrastructure Partners
thread.title_full: Asciano backs revised $12bn buyout bid backed by US fund Brookfield Infrastructure Partners

author: DANIEL PALMER
title: Asciano backs revised $12bn buyout bid backed by US fund Brookfield Infrastructure Partners
text:
SHARES in ports and logistics group Asciano have shared after the board agreed to a revised $12 billion takeover offer from a consortium led by a Canadian fund.
Brookfield Infrastructure Partners will secure a 55 per cent stake in Asciano under the deal.
Brookfield-sponsored and managed private funds will claim a further 23 per cent and two institutional partners will evenly split the remaining 22 per cent.
The deal, announced overnight Australian time, follows Asciano’s receipt of a non-binding proposal on June 26, with the two companies engaging in exclusive talks ever since.
Shares in the Melbourne-based company were up 9.9 per cent in morning trade at $8.11.
The final bid will provide Asciano shareholders with $6.94 in cash and 0.0387 shares in Brookfield Infrastructure for every Asciano share owned.
Prior to the US trading session overnight, the deal valued the target at $9.15 a share, although a 2 per cent drop in Brookfield’s share price overnight has dragged it back to $9.10 a share.
Asciano stock last traded at $8.11.
Shareholders will also have the opportunity to receive 90c of the $6.94 a share payout by way of a fully franked special dividend, which could provide an extra 39c of value for eligible shareholders.
Asciano board members have unanimously backed the offer, which comes in at a 39 per cent premium to port operator's share price prior to the offer surfacing in June.
"After careful consideration of all the options available to the company, the Asciano board has unanimously concluded that a sale of the company at a significant premium to market value, and on terms that we think reflect fair value, is in the best interests of all shareholders,” Asciano chairman Malcolm Broomhead said.
The agreement will see Brookfield pursue a listing on the ASX, for which it has received in-principal approval.
The deal still requires a shareholder vote, with a minimum support threshold of 75 per cent needing to be met. The vote is scheduled for mid November.
Clearance from regulators, including the Foreign Investment Review Board and Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, is also required.
The full details of the initial cash-and-scrip offer were kept quiet, though Asciano said it valued its stock around $9.05 a share.
However, from the time the offer first surfaced until the end of last week, Brookfield’s share price had retreated more than 6 per cent, meaning the original non-binding proposal had likely drifted below $9 a share.
Originally published as Asciano backs $12bn Brookfield bid
